wordpressPost.title: Going Nomadic
wordpressPost.content:
Two years ago, in September 2017, I went to India with a couple friends to do a 10-day Vipassana meditation course. We sat in silence with the other folks attending until the last day when we were finally allowed to converse with the people we’d spent so much time with. Among the people a father and son—the only other Americans there—who were taking the course as the first stop before traveling and working as digital nomads. I had never heard the term “digital nomad” before that point, but it intrigued me—going anywhere in the world you want while working from your laptop. I didn’t know it then, but that would become the most impactful part of the trip—not the meditation that I had gone there for.

In the next two years the thought of becoming a digital nomad never really left me. Eventually, in October 2019 I left my job at Cerner, a healthcare IT company based in Kansas City, to work for Automattic, a fully-distributed company known best for running WordPress.com. With employees spread out around the world, the timezone I was in didn’t really matter that much anymore. I did a quick round of visits to friends in Minneapolis, St. Paul, Des Moines, and Washington, D.C. before spending some time with my family over Christmas and New Year’s.

Today, I arrived in Lisbon, Portugal with everything I need packed into my 33L travel backpack. I’ll be here for a month. Wish me luck!
